Award.AwardTitle: University of Georgia Research Foundation/R/V Savannah/SSSE
Award.AbstractNarration:
A request is made to fund Shipboard Scientific Support Equipment for the Research Vessel Savanna, a 92 foot coastal research vessel, owned and operated by Skidaway Institute of Oceanography as part of the University-National Oceanographic Laboratory System (UNOLS) research fleet.

Since being put into service in the fall of 2001, this coastal/local class research vessel has proven to be a capable and cost-effective platform for a range of research and education projects. The primary working area for the vessel has been the continental shelf, coastal and estuarine environments of the Southeastern United States. The ship has also conducted cruises that have crossed the Gulf Stream into the western Sargasso Sea and as far as Curacao in the SE Caribbean. The R/V Savannah has been specifically designed with a large science berthing capacity to provide learning opportunities in ocean and estuarine environments and to demonstrate oceanographic research methodologies to diverse and often under-served student populations. These educational experiences continued in 2014, with the vessel hosting 80 graduate and undergraduate students and 16 high school and middle school teachers on 8 of its cruises. In 2014, the R/V Savannah completed 165 days at sea. NSF funded projects accounted for 92 days (56%) of the total sailing schedule.

The 2015 request is for replacement of Trawl Winch on R/V Savannah. The cost is $431,236

The principal impact of the present proposal is under Merit Review Criterion 2 of the Proposal Guidelines (NSF 13-589). It provides infrastructure support for scientists to use the vessel and its shared-use instrumentation in support of their NSF-funded oceanographic research projects (which individually undergo separate review by the relevant research program of NSF). The acquisition, maintenance and operation of shared-use instrumentation allows NSF-funded researchers from any US university or lab access to working, calibrated instruments for their research, reducing the cost of that research, and expanding the base of potential researchers.

POR.DRECONTENT:
A Hawboldt Industries SPR-2048/RS multipurpose winch funded under this award was successfully installed on the R/V Savannah in March of 2017 during a routine shipyard period (Figure 1).  This winch replaces a Markey DUP-8 winch on the ship’s O1 deck and serves as the primary component to the A-frame overboard handling system (OHS). The R/V Savannah's main winch was installed when the vessel was built in 2001, and has served the oceanographic community well. However, this winch lacks any type of monitoring for haul in/out speed, amount of wire in/out or operational wire tension; capabilities now considered standard for any modern oceanographic winch. Without tension member monitoring, the  winch must be operated at a factor of safety = 5, according to UNOLS RVSS Appendix A, restricting the heavy lifting capability that is often required in trawling, mooring and buoy service operations. Even with these  operational restrictions, including requirements for calculating the Maximum Allowable Operating Tension (MAOT) for each operation, without tension monitoring it is still possible to exceed established safe working parameters. After a through examination, it was determined that retrofitting the current winch to meet new safety standards was problematic and not cost effective. Instead, this proposal requested that a new winch be developed and installed on the Savannah for future operations.

The new winch has increased the safe working load of the OHS, provided tension monitoring, and added an auto render feature for increased safety.  In addition, the drum capacity has increased to allow for deeper operations. The winch is a modern addition to the shipboard ewuipment available on the Savannah.  After over a year in service on the ship, the winch has performed to specifications, increased ship capabilities, and enhanced safety. The enhanced safety that the new winch brings is of particular importance.  An oceanographic research vessel, such as the Savannah, carries not only a professional crew, but also scientists and students actively involved in oceanographic field studies. The safety of the science team, and the ship's crew, is of paramount importance.

The new winch meets all the specifications listed in the statement of work for this proposal.

Nearly every project supported off the Savannah has benefited from the new winch (Figure 2). The vessel is now able to work in deeper water depths, and handle larger, heavier equipment and moorings over the side.
